sn10.5:1.1: The commentary explains that Sānu was a disillusioned novice who had returned home planning to disrobe. | Sānu was perhaps named after the planet Saturn (Sanskrit śani; cf. SN 10.7). The Sanskrit word for planet (graha, cf. Pali gayha at DN 20:17.3) shows their role as “seizers”. The later Suśrutasaṁhitā-uttaratantra details the entities that cause such seizures in children (60), corresponding to the nine planets (27). Seizures or fits were treated as medical, spiritual, and astrological in cause and remedy.
sn10.5:1.2: Elsewhere we find possession by Māra expressed as anvāviṭṭha, literally “inhabited”, where the victims are made to behave badly but are otherwise normal (SN 4.18:1.4, MN 50:14.2; cf. Sanskrit āviṣṭa). Gahita here is also used for Rāhu “seizing” the Sun and Moon (SN 2.10:1.2). The commentary says he was shaking on the ground, eyes rolling and mouth foaming, i.e. having a “seizure”. This was not ill-motivated, for the yakkha was trying to prevent him from disrobing. Compare those who, though “seized by a gandharva” (gandharvagṛhīta), remain perfectly cogent (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.3.1, 3.7.1).
sn10.5:1.3: PTS editions insert an extra verse below, but it seems to be a scribal error.
sn10.5:2.1: See AN 3.70 for a detailed description of the eight-factored sabbath.
sn10.5:6.2: It’s interesting that the Buddha cites a yakkha saying to someone recovering from a yakkha-induced seizure. At Thig 12.1:12.1 these lines are attributed to the nun Puṇṇikā.
sn10.5:8.1: Sānu has recovered from his seizure to see his weeping mother. This verse appears without any context at Thag 1.44.
sn10.5:9.1: Here’s the plot twist: the mother’s real worry is not the seizure, but that her son will fall prey to desire and suffering. See SN 20.10:3.5, “For it is death in the training of the Noble One to reject the training and return to a lesser life.”
sn10.5:10.3: This is, I think, the only case in the EBTs where “inferno” might be suggested for naraka. Elsewhere in early Pali, however, it means “cliff, abyss” (MN 49:5.9, mn86:6.15](), Snp 3.11:28.4, Thag 16.8:4.2).
sn10.5:11.1: Here we see the origin of the term of address bhante, i.e. “good luck to thee”.
